title: How To Train Your Dog To Toilet Outside
summary: You donâ€™t need to spend hours training your dog, but you do need to be consistent. Start by picking one area of your garden and telling your dog to toilet there on a regular basis. Reward your dog with praise or playtime if they do their business there. If your dog has an accident inside, you need to ignore it and act as if it didn't happen. Spray vinegar or bitter spray around the garden to discourage your dog from using it. This is the best way to train a dog and it is something that should continue to do throughout their life.

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Your dog might have been house-trained as a puppy, but that doesn\u2019t mean they won\u2019t have accidents as an adult. Maybe you\u2019ve just moved to a new home and your dog hasn\u2019t gotten used to the new smells yet, or maybe he has medical issues that are causing him to have accidents. Whatever the reason, if your dog is having accidents in the house it can be distressing for both of you. However, with time and patience you can help your dog learn again how to toilet outside.
There are various reasons why a dog may stop using the indoor toilet. It may be as simple as them not liking it because of its location or smell or because there\u2019s another person or animal living in the house now who they don\u2019t like seeing when they do their business.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

content.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"Consistent Training"),mdx("p",null,`Just as you wouldn\u2019t expect your dog to understand the meaning of \u201Csit\u201D if you\u2019ve only ever said it once, you can\u2019t expect your dog to know what you mean if you only ever tell them to toilet outside once.
You don\u2019t need to spend hours training your dog, but you do need to be consistent.
Start by picking one area of your garden and telling your dog to toilet there on a regular basis.`),mdx("p",null,`If they do their business there, reward them with praise or playtime. If not, calmly take them back to that area and try again.
If your dog starts to go in that one area, gradually expand their toilet territory. Start by letting them use that area and then gradually move them on to using more of your garden.`),mdx("h2",null,"A Familiar Environment"),mdx("p",null,`Your dog is likely to be more comfortable toileting in a place they are familiar with. This can include their favourite patch of grass, a tree they\u2019ve always used or even the same spot they used when they were a puppy.
If your dog has always used the same area in your garden, try to keep them in that area during the initial toilet training process.
Your dog may be more relaxed and able to concentrate on their business if they are in a place they recognise.
Your dog may also be more relaxed about being in that place if they have always used it in the past.`),mdx("h2",null,"Reinforcing Good Behaviour"),mdx("p",null,`If your dog is toileting in the wrong places, you need to ensure that you\u2019re not rewarding them for their behaviour.
If your dog is toileting outside, you need to reward that. If they have an accident inside, you need to ignore it and act as if it didn\u2019t happen.
This is particularly important if there are other animals in the house or if there are children who are likely to make a fuss when they see an accident.`),mdx("p",null,"If your dog has had accidents inside and has been rewarded for doing so (e.g. because they weren\u2019t noticed), they may have learned that this is a successful way to behave."),mdx("h2",null,"Confining Your Dog When You\u2019re Away"),mdx("p",null,`If your dog is used to being let out on a regular basis, you may be able to keep them inside for short periods when you go out. This might help them learn to toilet indoors again as it will force them to go in the indoor toilet.
If your dog is house trained but is used to going out, you can gradually increase the amount of time they stay inside by putting them in a crate when you go out.
If your dog is not used to being confined, you should be careful not to leave them in there for too long as they may attempt to damage the crate.`),mdx("h2",null,"Spraying Bitter Spray Or Vinegar Around The Toilet"),mdx("p",null,`If there is a particular area of your garden that your dog continues to use, you may want to spray vinegar or bitter spray around that area for a short period to discourage your dog from using it.
This is particularly important if you have a garden that is not fenced off from your neighbours.
As with the other methods in this article, however, you need to make it clear to your dog that you don\u2019t want them to do their business in this area.
You may need to spray the area every day for several days in order to get the message across.`),mdx("h2",null,"Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,`Dogs are social creatures and often enjoy the company of their humans. If your dog is left alone for long periods, they may start to toilet inside out of boredom or anxiety. If this is the case, you should try to find ways to keep your dog busy while you are away. This can include playing with them or leaving a radio or TV on to provide background noise. You should also make sure your dog has enough toys and places to rest so that they don\u2019t get bored. If you have a dog who has been house trained but is now having accidents inside, it is important to try to find out why.
If your dog is toileting outside, there\u2019s no need to worry. This is the best way to train a dog, and it is something that you should continue to do throughout their life.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Train Your Dog Not to Bark Excessively

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:o,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:o,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Dogs bark for a variety of reasons and in different situations. Some dogs seem to bark much more than others, leading some owners to wonder how to train your dog not to bark excessively. When your dog barks excessively or at the wrong times, it can be annoying for you and other members of your household. You might find it difficult to get restful sleep when your dog won\u2019t stop barking or cries whenever you leave the house.
There are many reasons why dogs bark, but one thing is certain \u2013 excessive barking can be annoying and stressful for both dogs and their owners. Fortunately, there are ways to train your dog not to bark so frequently and effectively. Read on to discover how you can curb your dog\u2019s excessive barking quickly and easily!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Get over a Break-Up

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In the unfortunate event that you find yourself in a situation where you need to get over a break-up, it\u2019s important to know what to do in order to help the healing process along. Break-ups are never easy, and they can be even more difficult and hurtful if it\u2019s with your first love or someone you really cared about. These tips will help get you through any heartbreak and back into a place of peace.
When you experience a break-up, whether it\u2019s from a partner, friend or family member, it leaves you with an empty feeling. It hurts so much because you placed so many emotions into the relationship that it now feels like a part of who you are has been taken from you. Even though the person who broke up with you may have been oblivious to the pain they were causing by ending things, that doesn\u2019t make breaking up any easier for anyone involved.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Deal with Trust Issues in Relationships

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`When you first start dating someone, trust probably isn\u2019t the biggest issue on your mind. You\u2019re getting to know this person and trying to figure out if there might be a potential future with them or not. However, once you get into a relationship with this person and things get more serious, trust can very quickly become an issue.
Even if you don\u2019t trust someone right away, that doesn\u2019t mean the trust issues don\u2019t come up later on. It may take time for them to make you feel uneasy or distrustful of your partner. But it also could be something that crops up almost immediately \u2013 especially if you meet them in a place like a nightclub, bar or other place where people tend to hookup without much thought as to who they\u2019re hooking up with! This article will offer some tips on how to deal with these trust issues in relationships and help resolve any problems from arising in the first place.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Train Your Dog to Leave It

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Perhaps the most frustrating thing about owning a dog is that your house can never really be your own again. Fussing and fuming won\u2019t make them any less likely to follow you anywhere, or to notice that bag of chips you just carelessly threw on the table. Dogs are dogs, which means they will follow your slightest lead and chip in with their two cents at every opportunity. Sadly, this also means that it\u2019s not uncommon for dogs to get into things they shouldn\u2019t. You like peace and quiet? Not so much when there\u2019s a dog around. You like keeping your things? Good luck with that.
But luckily, with some bit of training and persistence, you can teach your pup exactly what\u2019s off limits and exactly where to leave it instead. Best of all, all these tricks take very little time and effort on our part. It doesn\u2019t have to be hard! Let\u2019s check out how!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always Travelling
How to Train Your Dog Not to Jump on People

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Do you have friends who are scared of dogs? Or perhaps you just don\u2019t want your dog jumping up on people. Whatever the case, teaching your dog to not jump up on people is an essential skill. It can also be tricky because it requires reading your dog and anticipating their behavior. If they haven\u2019t jumped yet, will they leap again? Will they creep towards you first or wait for you to move closer first? The answer may be different every time and that\u2019s why it can feel like a constant guessing game. However, with persistence and patience, you can train your dog to not jump on people.
If your dog is prone to jumping, it\u2019s important to manage that behavior before moving onto this training program. Dogs commonly jump for one of three reasons: They are excited and overstimulated; they want something from you such as food or attention; or they see it as a way of getting nearer to something else (this could be either the person you don\u2019t want them leaping at or something else nearby).`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always Working

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Working too much is a problem many people struggle with \u2014 but it\u2019s even more challenging when you\u2019re in a relationship with someone who has the same work ethic. If your partner usually leaves for work before you even get out of bed, or isn\u2019t home until after you\u2019re already in bed, things can get tricky.
Working from home, flexible hours and remote working are all buzzwords in today\u2019s labor market. Companies are becoming increasingly aware that it isn\u2019t just about how much time employees spend at the desk but also about what they achieve during that time. A Gallup poll found that telecommuting or working from home is growing in popularity among professionals across most industries. Working remotely makes it easier to find jobs, negotiate schedules and live without a commute.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
